channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: See the Hipster in his Natural Perl Environment
item.description: Our client provides a platform for musicians and industry professionals to manage their work and while making sure they get paid for it. If you support independent music, or if youâ€™re just a fan of artists getting compensated enough to drop the â€œstarvingâ€ part from their title, then this might be the job for you.

item.title: A Perl Equation that just Makes Sense
item.description: This well-known company builds the that software hosting companies use to allow customers to build websites. The software you create will be deployed on thousands of servers all over the internet, and used by hundreds of thousands of people! Best of all, the client has a killer relocation program, so if you land this one, itâ€™s Houston, here you come.

item.title: Superheroes Spotted in Canary Wharf! Perl Developer in London
item.description: Look there, up in the sky: Itâ€™s a birdâ€”itâ€™s a planeâ€”itâ€™s you, saving UK job hunters from disaster one click at a time! Could you be the next Captain Career Search or Wonder Worker? If youâ€™ve ever dreamed of donning the tights and mask, or even if you think you havenâ€™t got the legs for the tights but would like to make a difference to people all over the UK, then read on.

item.title: DevOps Daredevil Ready for Double Black Diamond Adventure
item.description: The client helps charities fundraise online and manages online payment systems for landlords, so youâ€™ll have the satisfaction of knowing youâ€™re contributing to the greater good. And if thatâ€™s not enough for you, did we mention the annual company ski trip AND the chance to work in the mountains near Lake Geneva for a week each year, all expenses paid? Giving back never felt so good!

item.title: Enjoy Modern Perl with a properly Agile team in Manchester; mid-Level Perl Developer
item.description: Tired of seeing endless London-based Perl jobs? Want to program Modern Perl in the Glorious North instead, where the people are friendly, the tea tastes right? The company is profitable, well-established, and family-owned, and have a strong set of benefits, not least of which a most-excellent coffee machine.

item.title: The Perl Conference 2020
item.description: June 23-27 2020 Houston, TX

item.title: DC-Baltimore Perlyglot Workshop (DCBPW) 2020
item.description: April 18-19 2020 Baltimore, MD

item.title: Jenkins
item.description: The Jenkins series was updated by two new examples: Jenkins triggers: Periodic polling and How to set the job number and description for a Jenkinsfile in a Jenkins Pipeline?.

item.title: Day 7 - Parsing Firefox' user.js with Raku
2019.48 Released Advent
item.description: A new compiler release of the Raku programming language.

item.title: Process the 6 headers of Markua
item.description: Parsing Markua, the magical typewriter.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 37: Week Days in Each Month and Daylight Gain/loss
item.description: I am a big fan of Laurent writing skill and his analytical skill. He is simply the best.

item.title: PERL WEEKLY CHALLENGE â€“ 037
item.description: I enjoyed Raku solutions more this time. It was written in Perl style.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 037: Weekdays and Daylight Gain/Loss
item.description: Choroba never misses the opportunity to use CPAN module. This time also he used the lovely Time::Piece to solve weekdays task.

item.title: Sunrise and Sunset in Perl
item.description: The use of CPAN module DateTime::Event::Sunrise was a surprise package. Thanks Dave for introducing the distribution.

item.title: Weekdays, Daylight and Raku
item.description: This week, I found Raku solutions easy to follow. Arne had his magic all over as always.

item.title: Weekdays and Daytimes
item.description: Adam went one step further and fetched the data using web scraping technique. A very good use of HTML::TableExtract.

item.title: Meet The Champion - Duane Powell
item.description: Please check out the short interview with the "Perl Weekly Challenge - 036" winner Duane Powell.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 037
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 038
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Maintaining Perl 5 (Tony Cook): October 2019 Grant Report
Maintaining the Perl 5 Core (Dave Mitchell): Grant Report for October / November 2019
Rewriting Perl Code for Raku III: The Sorceror
Asking for Rakudo.js grant feedback
item.description: Work on the Rakudo.js grant has been completed and Pawel is at the stage where community feedback is needed.

item.title: Grants: November 2019 Votes
item.description: 'Implement Perl Binding for libuv' was approved.

item.title: 2020 Vision
item.description: Dave seemed to have a lot of very similar ideas and initiatives to mine, except that his usually came a few years earlier. Two come to mind: organizing a local Perl Mongers group and having a Perl presence at FOSDEM, but there were more. I am looking forward to his ideas now so I'll know what I will come up in a few years from now. So yeah, good luck with them!

item.title: Working with CSV files using PDL
item.description: I am glad to see someone posting about PDL. Make it regular and PDL might get some more use.

item.title: Constant Platypus
item.description: A common challenge in calling C functions from any language other than C or C++ is dealing with constants.

item.title: #437 - DC-Baltimore Perlyglot Workshop (DCBPW) in April
item.description:
Hi everyone!

The DC-Baltimore Perlyglot Workshop (DCBPW) was just announce. It will take place April 18-19 2020 in Baltimore, MD. Perl, Raku and all programming languages and tools are welcome and encouraged topics at this event. Both CFP and registrations are now open, but note, the CFP closes January 6th. So submit your proposal now!

In other news, this week I have not seen the regular lists from Miguel Prz. I hope he is OK.

As usual, the Perl Weekly Challenge take a large part of the content.

Enjoy your week!
